[frozen] After fifteen years you walk through, [shaking], my door holding that piece of paper like nothing happened. [long pause]
[bitter] Um, well, I know.

[defensive] You tracked me here to this, [desperate], quiet workshop where I bind books and pretend the past, [hollow], doesn't exist, where I've made something, [breaking], peaceful from all that blood.

[soft] The bounty must be worth a fortune by now, [calculating], enough to retire on, enough to finally, [tired], stop hunting.

[wavering] Twenty years of compound interest makes it worth more than, [swallowing hard], either of us ever dreamed about back when we were partners, [distant], back when we trusted each other with, [pained], everything.

[angry] A note doesn't heal a shoulder full of shrapnel or explain, [betrayed], why you took our entire score and left me, [voice cracking], bleeding in that warehouse.

[exhausted] That funeral was staged to protect her from our enemies who would have, [heavy], used her against us, against, [meaningful], me.

[hurt] So our entire partnership was built on, well, um, lies and I was just the convenient, [bitter], muscle who didn't need to know the truth, [disgusted], who didn't deserve to know anything real about, uh, you.
You knew the real me in every way that, [earnest], mattered, except for this one impossible secret that would have, [regretful], destroyed everything.
[conflicted] I've carried this bounty for two decades, [struggling], waiting for any trace of Marcus Blackwood to surface.
[resigned] So what happens now that you've found him, [steady], or what's left of him in this bookbinder who just wants to, [pleading], forget. [sighs deeply]
The man who put out this bounty died, [revealing], three winters ago in prison.
Then why did you, um, even bother coming here if there's, [confused], no one left to pay you, I mean, what's the point now. [bewildered]

[vulnerable] Maybe I just needed to see your face when I, um, told you that I never stopped, [emotional], looking, not for the money but because, well, leaving things unfinished is like carrying glass in your chest.
[thawed] Would you like some tea while we, um, figure out how to properly, [gentle], bury Marcus Blackwood and let him rest, well, forever. [hopeful pause]
